subject: Learning
title: The Myth of Digital Natives
description: A quick, practical guide to The Myth of Digital Natives.

hook.text: Schools assumed Gen Z could navigate technology intuitively. Then they couldn't manage file folders.

buildup.text: The 'digital native' label led educators to skip teaching digital literacyâ€”assuming kids had it.

discovery.text: Studies show students raised on touchscreens struggle with keyboards, email, and professional software.

twist.text: Consuming content on a phone builds no transferable tech skills. Swiping is not computing.

climax.text: The myth cost a generation proper digital education by assuming exposure equals competence.

punchline.text: Digital familiarity isn't digital fluency. One must be taught.

quiz.question: How did the digital native myth harm students?
options: Schools skipped digital literacy instruction assuming kids already had it
Students were taught too much about technology
Only older students were affected by the myth
